Toronto stocks ended weaker on Wednesday, shedding Tuesday's gains as interest rate jitters and the Bre-X Minerals saga dragged the market lower.
The TSE 300 Composite Index fell 51.23 points to 5849.14 in brisk turnover of 90.7 million shares worth C$1.36 billion.
Declining stocks outpaced advances 549 to 400 with 292 issues unchanged.

The key index lost slightly more than the 50.15 points it gained during Tuesday's session. "The market was spooked by the fear of rising (U.S.) interest rates," said Ira Katzin, an investment advisor with RBC Dominion Securities.
On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average sank 94 on investor fears that a further hike in U.S. interest rates will signal a slowing economy and weaker growth in corporate profits.

"Of course, Canadian rates would have to follow suit or the Canadian dollar would collapse," Katzin said. The Canadian currency ended firmer on Wednesday, but analysts expect the recent weak trend to continue if Friday's U.S. payrolls data show signs of inflation.
The other major weight of the Toronto market was Bre-X Minerals Ltd and its controversial Busang gold discovery.
Shares in the Canadian gold prospector resumed trading on Wednesday, but massive trading volumes again overwhelmed a creaky computer system on the Toronto Exchange.
Bre-X fell 0.65 to 3.20 on massive volume of 11.7 million shares before trading was stopped due to technical problems.
Trading was not interrupted on the Montreal Exchange where Bre-X closed down 0.35 at 3.15 on 6.1 million shares.
Among other hot stocks:
* Bema Gold Corp rose 0.70 to 10.30 on 1.8 million shares after the mining firm released favourable resources estimates for a Chilean gold project.
